abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Highway Sector
            Investment Program Project is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as likely, institutional development impact
            as sustainable, Bank performance as satisfactory, and
            borrower performance as satisfactory. The Country Assistance
            Strategy and the project objectives have been consistent.
            The project design also closely reflected the
            government's priorities as set out in their Road Sector
            Expenditure Program for 1996-2000. The Bank also helped to
            underscore the need to halt negotiated contracts, bring the
            major cause of the arrears problem to a close. Key lessons
            learned are as follows: The study undertaken to monitor the
            poverty impact of road rehabilitated and maintained under
            the project established direct correlation between improved
            road condition and access to higher order social facilities.
            The study also found other benefits accruing to people
            living along the rehabilitated roads. The project attests to
            the importance of program concept, which recognizes that
            road networks are interdependent, and thus improvements and
            extensions to the network must be planned within the context
            of the whole. The arrears to contractors in the sector shows
            clearly the need for comprehensive road sector management
            and transparent reporting. The government needs to institute
            a procurement policy to promote transparency. Development
            partners need to have better coordination to avoid
            duplication of technical assistance provision.
